threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

HG101 for some reason are seen as authorities, when they're really just clueless retards. Sadly since they're often the ONLy english online source talking about a Japan only game, their word is often seen as gospel.

> Her name is Silphia (yes, different from the title).

I have no clue whose ass this was pulled from, but her name is Sylphia (spelled "シルフィア" in japanese). This is a blatant example of HG101 perpetuating factually incorrect information.

>As she lays dying, a force resurrects her as a fairy, giving her a second chance against the forces of evil.

Asshole is just watching the opening cutscene (which anyone can do) and just describing it without understanding it. She's chosen as a champion of the gods, and embued with the power of the Gods. Either Zeus or Athena.

>Sylphia was published by Tonkinhouse, and technically Compile’s name is never mentioned anywhere. However, its credits indicate that many of their staff members worked on it. Takayuki Hirono is listed as the “Game System Adviser”, and several programmers and artists, including Kouji “Janus” Teramoto are part of Compile’s regular staff. So it was definitely subcontracted to them, either in part or in full.

Compile staff did work on it, but he's speculating that it was formally outsourced to them. In truth, I have no clue what the backstory to the game is - but more critically neither does Kurt. Most sources will list Sylphia as a Compile game (such as mobygames), but Tonkinhouse is the only listed developer for it.

https://web.archive.org/web/20220904174026/http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/sylphia/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
My parents actually skipped dial-up. We had a computer (Macintosh Performa 631CD from Sears), but it didn't have a modem or any networking of any kind, and didn't communicate with the outside world. My first online experience was playing Starcraft with my friends over Battlenet, on our then-new iMac with a 768k DSL connection. It was an absolutely mind-blowing, magical experience. I completely skipped over the janky 56k experience most people had, and jumped into what online gaming was supposed to be.

>>9419753
I remember the wait for the Mac OS version of UT99. All my friends got the game for Christmas of 1999 and they were all playing each other online, but the Mac OS version was inexplicably delayed to January of the following year. I missed out on a lot in those three weeks but I'm glad for the good times playing that game in the early 2000s. I agree something's been lost, modern servers definitely don't have the same vibe, and it's not just me getting older.

>>9419790
I actually still play Brood War and Rise of Nations with my friends. Aside from that it's been years since I've played online with random people, it's just not something I enjoy anymore.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: It’s far better than you think
threads.com:
Behold, the Bandai wonderswan. The superior 90s handheld that deserves far more credit than it receives

With a library matching the Dreamcast in number and variety, it’s 200 games cover genres that portable gaming frankly sucked at beforehand.

Here you’ll find some of the best strategy RPGs and fighters handhelds ever had to offer in 99.

Backed by the powerhouse that was square, the console got a lot of big name titles from the developer. Final fantasies, mystery dungeons, and a fucking clock tower- the selection of quality RPGs on the console kicks the shit out of what the gameboy color and NGPC was offering that same year.

Being the first handheld with a widescreen, it made real nice for fighting games and vertical puzzlers.

From pocket fighter to guilty gear, to digimon and one piece, the system has a healthy selection of fun brawlers that play very well on the small screen.

On the note of one piece, the console was notable for its anime tie ins. Bandai was a licensing powerhouse after all.

The system was quite capable too! Handily shitting all over the cpus of the gameboy and neo geo pocket- this was the only system of the 3 that could run a full ass web browser.

Nearly the entire library runs at 75 fps. Why? Idk but it’s quite nice. Games are smooth with lots of animation and fast clean scrolling. Hundreds of sprites dotting the screen without hiccup.
The system is no slouch in audio hardware either. Having a capable synth setup, AND cool ass sample capabilities- it has a sound that when used to full potential reminds me of some neo geo titles.

Despite the device being a properly capable 16 bit handheld for the time, the thing SIPS power. A single AA battery will keep the thing in active gameplay for well over 40 hours. That’s not 40 hours standby- that’s 40 hours of straight gameplay. On ONE battery. Gbc could barely muster 10 on 2 of the things.
This was also a console that only cost about $30 on release.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9418701
In 1998 the gameboy was going on 10 years old. It was pretty far out of the main stage light too. So I think that’s why multiple companies decided that then was the best time to come in with a competitor. It would be easier to get into the market with a shiny new thing when the other option is a ten year old console that’s old news.

They probably took a look at the game gear and the lynx and learned the lesson that the gameboy thought; that a color lit screen was secondary to things like battery life and price.

And then Pokémon happened, which in turn brought the console back into the spotlight. And the gameboy color was sort of a rush job sequel upgrade.
Some people say the GBC was a response to the ngp and WS. But I think it was more a case of terrible timing on Bandai and SNK’s part. Pokémon would have blown up and made the GBC happen regardless.

Either way the gbc came out, they both shat their pants and then made a color system asap

SNK especially. Not even a year later the color machine was out.
Only 11 games had made it to stores before they went all color. And to make it up to people who bought in early, SNK had most games be backwards compatible. Unlike the gameboy and WS where it’s just some of the color software working on the BW units, the majority of every color NGPC game has a black and white mode

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9419121
>the lynx and learned the lesson

The Lynx had a backlight button. The Game Gear does not (owned a Game Gear). The Nintendo Game Boy Pocket Light has this feature too.

>>9419121
>Some people say the GBC was a response to the ngp and WS. But I think it was more a case of terrible timing on Bandai and SNK’s part. Pokémon would have blown up and made the GBC happen regardless.

It was a combination of things. maybe also because Nintendo's Project Atlantis was delayed. Also Pokemon was big. Plus Bandai and SNK releasing handhelds. Project Atlantis was not the code name for the GBA, it was a different but kinda similar handheld. GBA was almost 'plan B' for Nintendo. Nintendo never considered the GBC to be a new handheld. Just an extension of the original GameBoy. They did it again with the DSi, and other later handhelds. Game Boy Color was just a spec upgrade on the GameBoy, faster CPU mode, more memory, can do 15bit colour, but is limited to NES style palettes.

I owned a Game Boy Color in 1999, I was like 18, and had a library of GameBoy games for my Super GameBoy adapter. because I hated the greenscreen GameBoy. I really liked the Game Boy Color screen. Also had SMB Deluxe, Metal Gear Solid, LA DX, Tetris DX, a dozen GB games. I thought the Neo-Geo Pocket Color looked cool as fuck, always wanted one. Could never find one. I owned a Dreamcast and wanted that link cable thing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9417243
Snow Leopard was really the end of the "old" Mac OS X. It was the last version to be distributed on a physical disc, it was the last version to focus solely on the local, physical computer (the app store was an afterthought update add-on), and it was the last version that wasn't part of the bullshit annual release cycle. Hell, for a while, it was the last version of the OS that had "Mac" in it. I eventually upgraded to El Capitan but it felt like something died along the way.

>>9417665
Macs were actually fairly common in Europe during the early 1990s. I remember reading an NYT article from 1992 where they said that Apple was the third-largest computer company in Europe by sales volume, behind only IBM and Compaq. Maybe they weren't common in Britain because there was actually a fairly healthy domestic computer scene in the UK, whereas Europe really lagged behind in that regard, which allowed foreign companies to enter the European market.

Macs weren't exactly widespread everywhere in North America, though. When I was growing up in suburban Calgary in the mid-to-late 1990s, I was literally the ONLY kid in my class of 25-ish who owned a Macintosh. Our school had a few Apple IIs scattered around the classrooms, probably holdouts from an earlier time. We never used them because nobody knew how to work them. Everything else was IBM compatible (manufactured by DEC, interestingly enough) running Windows NT 4.0.

Great series of articles, by the way. It's interesting to read about all the times where Steve Jobs ran interference for absolutely no fucking reason at all (eg, refusing to work with Sony on the 3.5" drives, refusing to include expansion slots when technology was evolving rapidly). I'm actually kind of surprised to see how rehabilitated he's become in vintage Apple circles and even here on 4chan, because 10 years ago he was almost universally derided as a marketing man who purposely gimped his own products.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9418454
>I'm actually kind of surprised to see how rehabilitated he's become in vintage Apple circles and even here on 4chan, because 10 years ago he was almost universally derided as a marketing man who purposely gimped his own products.
His philosophy was always of making single configuration appliance computers that could be sold and used like a radio or microwave.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9418454
I can’t think of one macOS release in the past decade that has impressed me in a big way, whereas every few years from 2000-2009, each release was drastically changing the way you interacted with the machine or adding tons of visible, new features. I remember being blown away by how cool Tiger and Leopard were, and how far ahead they seemed compared to the frustrating Windows experiences at the time.

>>9418467
Jobs’s philosophy was a great idea back when understanding computers meant you had to be a tinkerer or just patient with a steep learning curve. He and Ive took it too far after 2007, though, with trying to make your Mac into the IT equivalent of a washing machine or refrigerator. And I wouldn’t have an issue with making it ever simpler if it hadn’t also come with Apple’s repeated attempts to lock users out of anything “under the hood.”

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: >>9415693

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9419525
I remember being thoroughly impressed by Tiger, and it was definitely several steps ahead of Windows XP in terms of refinement. But I was absolutely blown away by Leopard, it was such a quantum leap forward. Even Snow Leopard, with "zero new features", impressed me because it was like Leopard but faster. A number of things have changed since then.

First, all of the older versions of Mac OS X had very long development lead times. Tiger was in development for 18 months, and Leopard was in development for over 2 years. Now, they're pumping out a new version of Mac OS every year. The Mac team doesn't really have enough time to refine the software or to fully think through the features, so we will often get a half-baked release like Yosemite which is followed up by a "stable" release like El Capitan. And speaking of the Mac team, the political environment inside Apple has now changed. The iPhone has eclipsed the Mac as Apple's flagship product. Anyone who wants to advance within Apple knows that they need to get on the iOS team, so all the best talent goes there. The core Mac team is comprised of the also-rans, and some of the lower performers from the iOS team are sent over to the Mac team. These people are not stupid by any means, after all they work for Apple, but they are not Apple's A-Team. Previously, Mac OS X releases were very polished because Apple had its very best and brightest working on them. That's not necessarily the case anymore. t. my brother worked for Apple for 3 years

>>9396717
It's funny that despite lacking memory protection and being theoretically unstable, in practice I remember Classic Mac OS crashing about as often as Windows 9x. I think the programming of the OS was generally pretty tight, which prevented it from devolving into a huge clusterfuck, whereas while Microsoft had a theoretically better design, their shit coding practices meant that in daily use it wasn't much better than something that SHOULD be massively inferior.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Whenever I'm looking through libraries of old games for something play I always wonder what happened to all the dead IPs. There used to be so much more variety back then, with big and small budget titles for every console. Some experimental, others trying revolutionize their own genre.
Nowadays you only ever see the famous long-lived companies releasing new games for the same 4~5 franchises they own, naturally because those survived the test of time, and the test of "how much money can we keep making with them".
In some cases they even refuse to acknowledge the existence of certain games that they've developed or published simply because they never sold well enough when competition was fierce, and are only remembered when someone makes a list of fun games of a specific genre for X or Y console. Forgotten Worlds, Captain Commando, Dirt Dash, Gradius, Bloody Roar, Comix Zone, Smashing Drive, all those other arcade machines and third party ventures that barely got two paragraphs worth of a description on Wikipedia, that only amounted to a sporadic "hey remember playing this game?" here or there.

It's just business of course, but I always end up wondering if videogames as a whole have only ever been a process of trimming the wheat from the chaff until you have a couple of golden eggs all along, and if all but the few most profitable titles are gone forever.

>>9416242
>out of nowhere
Different developer. The original developers did some fun things after that but it then fizzled out. The real issue was that the IP was mismanaged and that unlike with Konami, Eurocom didn't try to repurpose their Disney stuff as cheap assets for inhouse franchises later.

>>9416392
Not the same developer. There's a Lady Stalker for SNES and Time Stalkers on DreamCast but they're hardly the same thing.

If it helps, Landstalker is by Climax, this far a major Sega supporter.
Lady Stalker (SNES) exists because they felt they were snubbed by Sega, and Dark Savior (Saturn) exists because they made up but is only a shadow of its former self despite being billed as the evolution of Landstalker, and Time Stalkers is a generic 3D JRPG billed as a crossover, and Steel Princess (DS) is the only major time they revisited Landstalker's gameplay outside of the ill-fated PSP remake. Then they went defunct.

Climax had some staff exodus, and they founded Matrix Software. They did Alundra, published by Sony. It's largely a one-off game, and a sequel happened that had little to do with it.
There was some more staff exodus to Epics, and they did Popolocrois Monogatari, which is very similar to Landstalker. They continued, and the team is still together as late as 2020.

The tragedy behind Landstalker is that the talent and IP was scattered across multiple companies, and as time passed the isometric style and detailed pixel art quickly fell out of relevance then.

last_replies.com:
What a weird series.

>Murder Club
Localized on most platforms but not the Switch version
>Manhattan Requiem
Localized exclusively on a Laserdisc version, then the Android and Switch (import only) versions, and none else
>Kiss of Murder (spinoff)
>D.C. Connection (third main game)
No known localization
>Blue Chicago Blues
Localized exclusively for a Sega Laserdisc version, other versions replaced the English text but kept the audio, and then others redubbed the audio in Japanese.

Then the series was revived around 2006 with a remake of the first two games + the spinoff, for flip mobile phones, the Nintendo DS, iPhone, then the Nintendo Switch. Then those short new games were made between 2006-2007 but as Japanese mobile phone exclusives:
>Seattle Purple Haze
>San Francisco Black Bell
>The Solitary Dead -BOSTON SOLITARY CORPSE-

Rarely have I seen such an import-unfriendly series, which is bad considering how obviously inspired by America it is (to the point the scenario and major plot beats have been written in English at least once)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Favorite turnbased is probably the Advance Wars games. For small squad tactics stuff, Fallout Tactics played in realtime appealed to me the most.

Fallout Tactics isn't lore friendly, and it has pretty much zero actual roleplaying, regrettably, but the combat feels a million times better than the original games. True realtime combat doesn't give you comfortable time to think over every single move (and I never bothered much with setting your aim on anything but center mass by default, that shit works), but there's an added thrill to it all for the increased risk and speed, any calculated risk you take demands followthrough.

Since there's no roleplaying, you can dumpstat Charisma to put those points into other stats which actually matter for the gameplay, use Gifted to get those extra points. Yes, having only 2CHR means getting somewhat less favors, and not getting access to as good recruits, but the available ones are good enough and become better as they level, so it's fine to play as an autistic gunfighter.
Ambushes and breaching becomes particularly exciting because you need to carefully set them up in real time, get your guys into covered vantage points where they can reach the kill zone, make sure that none of them intersect with each other's line of fire (make them crouch down or lie down prone to achieve this if needed, you can shoot over people's heads just fine), maybe even set up some mines too.
Deathclaws are a bit more of a challenging proposition, as though you may be able to annihilate one with a burst of flechette shells from a select-fire shotgun, often they come in multiples and the survivor(s) will carve you up like a pig. Instead you need to absolutely fucking leg it after you've got their attention with your opening salvo, to then flee and let them rush into the field of automatic fire that you've set up right by a chokepoint.

>Gadget is hard to describe. Surreal and unsettling would be a good place to start. A weird curio from a bygone era? Yep. An avant-garde art piece? Yeah, probably that too. I'm hesitant to call it a good game, because it's barely a game at all, but I'll certainly say this... it's interesting.

>The game is extremely linear, mostly shuffling you around from location to location with a few things in any given environment to interact with and, once you do, you'll be shuffled off to the next area. This has the effect, intended or not, of making you feel rather uncomfortable as you're given virtually no control over anything. Practically every game amounts to simply doing what the developers intended, but it's rarely as on the nose as it is here, to the point that it feels less like exerting your own will and intellect to reach a desired conclusion that was planned by the developers and more like doing what they want, regardless of what you want. The distinction is arguably superficial but, in this case, it's palpable just the same.

>Graphically the game is a strange mishmash of steampunk, art deco, and some kind of unidentified Eastern Bloc country aesthetic. Things frequently take a turn for the surreal, and you often travel from one location to the next in something approximating an out of body experience - you'll be looking at a monitor of something and then suddenly move through the monitor into that location, for example.

>Adding to the surreal and unsettling quality is a fantastic, otherworldly soundtrack by Koji Ueno. It sometimes reminded me of the work of Akira Yamaoka, with things frequently turning into walls of abstract industrial noise. If the bizarre visuals and storytelling aren't enough to make you uneasy, the music ought to do the trick.

https://www.zombs-lair.com/gadget-collection

I just realized something that is a very big mark against Shenmue for me, even as a fan. The game aims to be realistic, so clearly that means that you won't be fighting every 30 seconds like its a Yakuza game, however, because of the lack of fighting it feels as if I never have the chance to get good at the actual combat. I noticed that every battle feels like me testing out moves to see if they work, like I'm fumbling around in practice mode in a fighting game, I never feel like I have the hang of this games fighting mechanics. Its not as if I lose the fights, but its never very satisfying because once I try and fail to be technical and thoughtful with my attack selection, I just default to mashing, regroup, and win anyway.

Perhaps its just me but it feels like a profound revelation right now.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: 5th console generation was the real golden age
threads.com:
People often say that 4th gen was the golden age, specifically SNES, because, because 2D matured enough to look good, while 5th gen was the period of experimentation and early 3D and thus did not age well. In fact, this is correct only for side scrolling platformer games. Genre by genre, 5th gen was the period when many genres, which were miserable during 4th gen, finally became great.
>Fighting games.
4th gen only had Street Fighter 2 ports which are still good. All other fighting games were compromised in various ways and are hard to get back to. Mortal Kombat, World Heroes, Art of Fighting, Fatal Fury - these were okayish 7.5/10 in arcades but home ports sucked big time with possible exception of SNES MK2. You didn't have great fighting experience on home consoles.
On 5th gen you have literal masterpieces like VF2, Tekken 2 and 3, SF Alpha games and other Capcom and SNK ports. Even on PS1, which is considered less desireable than Saturn for 2D fighting games, things like SFA or Real Bout shit all over any of the SNES or Genesis ports.
>Racing games
This is even easier. Daytona USA, Ridge Racer, Sega Rally, Gran Turismo, Need for Speed - these all are huge system sellers and still play great. SNES and Genesis have tons of racing games but they all are shovelware. Nothing on the level and prominence of the titles mentioned above. Out Run was good only on arcades.
>First person shooters
5th gen had Doom, Quake and Goldeneye. Nuff said. SNES Doom is more of a curiosity than a proper game. 16 bit consoles only had Wolfenstein and Zero Tolerance which is a Wolfenstein clone - both very simplistic and flat, compared to Doom.
>Real Time Strategy
There is Dune 2 on Genesis and that's it. Herzog Zwei is a strategy/shmup hybrid and is a different genre. Dune 2 is a very barebones game with only skirmish missions, bad controls and tons of slowdown. 5th gen consoles have proper RTS games with C&C, Red Alert and Warcraft 2 ports.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9417681
It's KIND of a traditional Mega Man platformer, but you find battle chips that basically work as subweapons by either locating them on stages or as occasional enemy drops. Chips don't get "used up", but collecting multiples will increase your ammuntion gauge for them, so grinding for them until you've maxed their gauge can be useful. You also have a weapon energy gauge that depletes every time you use a chip but recharges automatically, in order to prevent you from just spamming chips like crazy. There are also hidden permanent upgrades like max HP increases or max weapon energy increases, but no real rpg elements beyond those. It's kinda comparable to something like Zelda 2 I guess, just without an overworld or anything resembling puzzles.
